Comments: No mention in DISP
Control /Action: Control information posted or processed on publicly accessible information systems.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP mentions this under physical security from level 1 onwards where facilities are accredited
to receive, handle, store and destroy information and material, covered in detail under ISO 27002 11.2.7 Secure disposal or re-use of equipment
Control /Action: Sanitize or destroy information system media containing Federal Contract Information before disposal or release for reuse.

Control: Defence accreditation (IRAP assessor (expensive), Standalone device Defence network or device (dreams token, physical installation of DPN, DSN or TSN))
Comments: No mention in CMMC                          DISP requires defence accreditation of your network or standalone device (Levels 1,2,3)for entry level self accreditation with an IT service provider is allowed, CMMC does not
Control /Action: Get Defence accreditation of your network or standalone device

Control: Governance (CSO/SO – Chief Security Office/ Security Officer)
Comments: No mention in CMMC
Control /Action: Must have a nominated (CSO) and (SO) who must be able to meet AGSVA eligibility requirements for Baseline clearance)

Comments: No mention in CMMC
Control /Action: Report any substantial changes as soon as possible, including changes in Foreign Ownership, Control and Influence (FOCI) status

Comments: No mention in CMMC                                                        CMMC does not mention personnel clearance or the agency doing the clearance
Control /Action: Screening in tiered levels of Information access from official/sensitive, protected, secret and top secret

Comments: No mention in DISP
Control /Action: Control and monitor the use of mobile code.

Comments: No mention in DISP
Control /Action: Control and monitor the use of Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) technologies.

Comments: No mention in DISP
Control /Action: Control the flow of CUI in accordance with approved authorizations.

Comments: No mention in DISP
Control /Action: Enforce safeguarding measures for CUI at alternate work sites.

Comments: No mention in DISP
Control /Action: Limit use of portable storage devices on external systems.

Comments: No mention in DISP
Control /Action: Prohibit remote activation of collaborative computing devices and provide indication of devices in use to users present at the device.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP mentions this under physical security from level 1 onwards, covered in detail under ISO 27002 11.2.7 Secure
disposal or re-use of equipment
Control /Action: Protect (i.e., physically control and securely store) system media containing CUI, both paper and digital.

Comments: No mention in DISP
Control /Action: Provide privacy and security notices consistent with applicable CUI rules.

Comments: No mention in DISP
Control /Action: Require multifactor authentication to establish nonlocal maintenance sessions via external network connections and terminate such connections when nonlocal maintenance is complete.

Comments: No mention in DISP
Control /Action: Test the organizational incident response capability.

Comments: No mention in DISP
Control /Action: Control information posted or processed on publicly accessible information systems.

Control /Action: Control information posted or processed on publicly accessible information systems.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Alert in the event of an audit logging process failure.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP advice general use of password managers and change of admin default passwords, if ISO is used, this goes into detail and mentions use and change of temporary passwords under 9.3.1 use of secret authentication information
Control /Action: Allow temporary password use for system logons with an immediate change to a permanent password.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Analyze the security impact of changes prior to implementation.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC. Covered under ICT & Cyber depending on which cyber security standard is used in this case ISO 27001/27002
Control /Action: Apply deny-by-exception (blacklisting) policy to prevent the use of unauthorized software or deny-all, permit-by-exception (whitelisting) policy to allow the execution of authorized software.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Authorize remote execution of privileged commands and remote access to security-relevant information.

Comments: This is not mentioned in DISP but covered under ISO 27002 13.1.3 Segregation in networks Some items of access control are covered under governance and others under ICT & Cyber
Control /Action: Authorize wireless access prior to allowing such connections.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Check media containing diagnostic and test programs for malicious code before the media are used in organizational systems.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP covers in ICT and Cyber using ISO 27002 ,8.3 Media handling.
Control /Action: Control access to media containing CUI and maintain accountability for media during transport outside of controlled areas.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC Covered under ICT & Cyber depending on which cyber security standard is used in this case  ISO 27001/27002
Control /Action: Control and monitor user-installed software.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Control connection of mobile devices.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP covers depending on the chosen ICT and
Cyber standard, ISO covers under 8.3.1 Management of removable media
Control /Action: Control the use of removable media on system components.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Correlate audit record review, analysis, and reporting processes for investigation and response to indications of unlawful, unauthorized, suspicious, or unusual activity.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC  DISP uses DISO to audit systems and networks (checks maturity across all 4 domains)
Control /Action: Create and retain system audit logs and records to the extent needed to enable the monitoring, analysis, investigation, and reporting of unlawful or unauthorized system activity.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Define, document, approve, and enforce physical and logical access restrictions associated with changes to organizational systems.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC.   Not mentioned in DISP but briefly mentioned in ISO 27002 9.1.1 Access
control policy
Control /Action: Deny network communications traffic by default and allow network communications traffic by exception (i.e., deny all, permit by exception).

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Develop and implement plans of action designed to correct deficiencies and reduce or eliminate vulnerabilities in organizational systems.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP requires a current
security risk register or any other system of risk oversight and management
Control /Action: Develop, document, and periodically update system security plans that describe system boundaries, system environments of operation, how security requirements are implemented, and the relationships with or connections to other systems.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  This would be covered in detail under ISO 27002 if that is the chosen standard under 9.4.2 Secure log-on procedures
Control /Action: Disable identifiers after a defined period of inactivity.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP covers this under ICT and Cyber
depending on standard chosen, ISO 27002 14.2.5 Secure system engineering principles
Control /Action: Employ architectural designs, software development techniques, and systems engineering principles that promote effective information security within organizational systems.

Comments: Briefly mentioned in DISP under industry tip in ICT and Cyber then more comprehensively covered in ISO 27002
Control /Action: Employ cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality of remote access sessions.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP does not mention this, but depending on the chosen standard, ISO 27002 covers in 10.1 Cryptographic controls
Control /Action: Employ FIPS-validated cryptography when used to protect the confidentiality of CUI.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  This would be covered in detail under ISO 27002 if that is the chosen standard
Control /Action: Employ replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for network access to privileged and non-privileged accounts.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC Covered under ICT & Cyber depending on which cyber security standard is used in this case ISO 27002
Control /Action: Employ the principle of least functionality by configuring organizational systems to provide only essential capabilities.

Comments: Covered under ICT & Cyber depending on standard chosen, in this case ISO 27002
Control /Action: Employ the principle of least privilege, including for specific security functions and privileged accounts.

Comments: Covered under DISP ICT & Cyber depending on standard chosen, in this case ISO 27001/2
Control /Action: Encrypt CUI on mobile devices and mobile computing platforms.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  Only mentioned in CMMC, DISP does not explicitly cover but advice to consider individual security and choose the most appropriate authentication, this would be covered in detail under ISO 27002 if that is the chosen standard
Control /Action: Enforce a minimum password complexity and change of characters when new passwords are created.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Ensure equipment removed for off-site maintenance is sanitized of any CUI.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Ensure that managers, systems administrators, and users of organizational systems are made aware of the security risks associated with their activities and of the applicable policies, standards, and procedures related to the security of those systems.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP mentions this in terms of revalidating personnel
clearance depending on change of circumstances and discusses it further in an industry tip case scenario
Control /Action: Ensure that organizational systems containing CUI are protected during and after personnel actions such as terminations and transfers.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Ensure that personnel are trained to carry out their assigned information security-related duties and responsibilities.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP is brief
Control /Action: Ensure that the actions of individual system users, can be uniquely traced to those users so they can be held accountable for their actions.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP discusses this at length using Industry tip scenarios
Control /Action: Establish an operational incident-handling capability for organizational systems that includes preparation, detection, analysis, containment, recovery, and user response activities.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP uses a downloadable tool to establish baseline and align it with DISO cyber maturity model. It also recommends seeking service from IT service provider.
Control /Action: Establish and enforce security configuration settings for information technology products employed in organizational systems.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP briefly mentions this, then allows for choice of standard to be used.
Control /Action: Establish and maintain baseline configurations and inventories of organizational systems (including hardware, software, firmware, and documentation) throughout the respective system development life cycles.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP does not mention this, but depending on the chosen standard, ISO 27002 covers in 10.1.2 Key management
Control /Action: Establish and manage cryptographic keys for cryptography employed in organizational systems.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP using case studies and incidents and provide steps to follow
Control /Action: Identify unauthorized use of organizational systems.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP does not mention this, but depending on the chosen standard, ISO 27002 covers in 13.2.1 Information transfer policies and procedures
Control /Action: Implement cryptographic mechanisms to prevent unauthorized disclosure of CUI during transmission unless otherwise protected by alternative physical safeguards.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Implement cryptographic mechanisms to protect the confidentiality of CUI stored on digital media during transport unless otherwise protected by alternative physical safeguards.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC, for DISP access to information depends on level of
clearance. Physical security is divided into zones (1 to 5) with access controls in place, the security clearance levels determine the zone and material an
individual has access to.
Control /Action: Limit access to CUI on system media to authorized users.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Limit management of audit logging functionality to a subset of privileged users.

Comments: Covered under ICT & Cyber depending on standard chosen, in this case ISO 27002
Control /Action: Limit unsuccessful logon attempts.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  This is covered on DISP if ISO 27002 is used under 8.2.3 Handling of assets
Control /Action: Mark media with necessary CUI markings and distribution limitations.

Comments: Briefly mentioned in DISP under industry tip in ICT and Cyber, more comprehensively covered in ISO 27002
Control /Action: Monitor and control remote access sessions.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP briefly mentions on how to manage incidents and ISO mentions as well
Control /Action: Monitor organizational systems, including inbound and outbound communications traffic, to detect attacks and indicators of potential attacks.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Monitor security controls on an ongoing basis to ensure the continued effectiveness of the controls.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP advocates for system monitoring and provides further information on action response on case studies. This is further covered in ISO 12.4 Logging and monitoring
Control /Action: Monitor system security alerts and advisories and take action in response.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  This would be covered in detail under ISO 27002 if that is the chosen standard under 9.4.3 Password management system
Control /Action: Obscure feedback of authentication information.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP advice use of IT service provider to ensure the systems continuously meets standard.
Control /Action: Perform maintenance on organizational systems.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Periodically assess the risk to organizational operations (including mission, functions, image, or reputation), organizational assets, and individuals, resulting from the operation of organizational systems and the associated processing, storage, or transmission of CUI.

Comments: covered by both
Control /Action: Periodically assess the security controls in organizational systems to determine if the controls are effective in their application.

Comments: Covered under ICT & Cyber depending on standard chosen, in this case ISO 27002
Control /Action: Prevent non-privileged users from executing privileged functions and capture the execution of such functions in audit logs.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.   Not mentioned in DISP, but it can be considered covered under ISO 6.2.2 Teleworking if ISO27002 is covered
Control /Action: Prevent remote devices from simultaneously establishing non-remote connections with organizational systems and communicating via some other connection to resources in external networks (i.e., split tunneling).

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  This would be covered in detail under ISO 27002 if that is the chosen standard under 9.4.2 Secure log-on procedures
Control /Action: Prevent reuse of identifiers for a defined period.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP covers this under ICT and Cyber
depending on standard chosen, ISO 27002 discusses further under 12.1.4 Separation of development, testing and operational environments
Control /Action: Prevent unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  This would be covered in detail under ISO 27002 if that is the chosen standard
Control /Action: Prohibit password reuse for a specified number of generations.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP covers depending on the chosen ICT and
Cyber standard, ISO 27001/2 covers
Control /Action: Prohibit the use of portable storage devices when such devices have no identifiable owner.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Protect and monitor the physical facility and support infrastructure for organizational systems.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Protect audit information and audit logging tools from unauthorized access, modification, and deletion

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP does not mention this, depending on standard chosen, ISO 27002 13
Communications security
Control /Action: Protect the authenticity of communications sessions.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  DISP briefly mentions this and further
discusses on ICT and cyber and provides a comprehensive coverage of physical security of back up data, ISO 27002 covers under 12.3.1 Information backup
Control /Action: Protect the confidentiality of backup CUI at storage locations.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  DISP does not explicitly mention this, under ICT and Cyber, ISO 27002 covers under 18.1.3 Protection of records
Control /Action: Protect the confidentiality of CUI at rest.

Comments: This is not mentioned in DISP but covered under ISO 27002 13.1.2 Security of network services
Control /Action: Protect wireless access using authentication and encryption.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  Only indirectly implied in DISP but explicitly discussed in ISO 27002, 12.7 Information systems audit considerations
Control /Action: Provide a system capability that compares and synchronizes internal system clocks with an authoritative source to generate time stamps for audit records.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Provide audit record reduction and report generation to support on-demand analysis and reporting.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP accepts self- certification at entry level and uses CIOG (defence authority for accrediting systems) for all levels above 1 This is comprehensively covered in ISO 27002 if that is the chosen ICT standard under 14.2.2 System change control procedures
Control /Action: Provide controls on the tools, techniques, mechanisms, and personnel used to conduct system maintenance.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Provide security awareness training on recognizing and reporting potential indicators of insider threat.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP maintains an insider threat program with clear escalation pathways
Control /Action: Remediate vulnerabilities in accordance with risk assessments.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC Covered under ICT & Cyber depending on which cyber security standard is used in this case ISO 27001/2
Control /Action: Restrict, disable, or prevent the use of nonessential programs, functions, ports, protocols, and services.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC briefly
Control /Action: Review and update logged events.

Comments: Briefly mentioned in DISP under ICT and Cyber on securing cloud services
Control /Action: Route remote access via managed access control points.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Scan for vulnerabilities in organizational systems and applications periodically and when new vulnerabilities affecting those systems and applications are identified.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  Both models cover screening, DISP goes into details in depth about its screening
process in line with AS 4811-2006 employment screening process and maintains a DSAP list for clearance levels it also requires a description of the
screening process. DISP also mentions SO sponsoring clearances.
Control /Action: Screen individuals prior to authorizing access to organizational systems containing CUI.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC  Mentioned briefly on DISP, covered under ICT and Cyber depending on standard chosen.
Control /Action: Separate the duties of individuals to reduce the risk of malevolent activity without collusion.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP covers this under ICT and Cyber
depending on standard chosen, ISO 27002 discusses further under 9.1.2 Access to networks and network services
Control /Action: Separate user functionality from system management functionality.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.   This would be covered in detail under ISO 27002 if that is the chosen standard under 9.4.2 Secure log-on procedures
Control /Action: Store and transmit only cryptographically protected passwords.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP is covered under ISO 27002
11.2.4 Equipment maintenance
Control /Action: Supervise the maintenance activities of maintenance personnel without required access authorization.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Terminate (automatically) a user session after a defined condition.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP briefly covers this under ICT and Cyber and discusses further on ISO 27002 9.4.2 Secure log-on procedures
Control /Action: Terminate network connections associated with communications sessions at the end of the sessions or after a defined period of inactivity.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP requires maintain an inside thereat program with risks and mitigation strategies
Control /Action: Track, document, and report incidents to designated officials and/or authorities both internal and external to the organization

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Track, review, approve or disapprove, and log changes to organizational systems.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Use multifactor authentication for local and network access to privileged accounts and for network access to non-privileged accounts.

Comments: Covered under ICT & Cyber depending on standard chosen, in this case ISO 27002
Control /Action: Use non-privileged accounts or roles when accessing nonsecurity functions.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Use session lock with pattern-hiding displays to prevent access and viewing of data after a period of inactivity.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  This is covered on DISP if ISO 27002 is used under 8.2.3 Handling of assets
Control /Action: Mark media with necessary CUI markings and distribution limitations.

Comments: Briefly mentioned in DISP under industry tip in ICT and Cyber, more comprehensively covered in ISO 27002
Control /Action: Monitor and control remote access sessions.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP briefly mentions on how to manage incidents and ISO mentions as well
Control /Action: Monitor organizational systems, including inbound and outbound communications traffic, to detect attacks and indicators of potential attacks.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Monitor security controls on an ongoing basis to ensure the continued effectiveness of the controls.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP advocates for system monitoring and provides further information on action response on case studies. This is further covered in ISO 12.4 Logging and monitoring
Control /Action: Monitor system security alerts and advisories and take action in response.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  This would be covered in detail under ISO 27002 if that is the chosen standard under 9.4.3 Password management system
Control /Action: Obscure feedback of authentication information.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP advice use of IT service provider to ensure the systems continuously meets standard.
Control /Action: Perform maintenance on organizational systems.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Periodically assess the risk to organizational operations (including mission, functions, image, or reputation), organizational assets, and individuals, resulting from the operation of organizational systems and the associated processing, storage, or transmission of CUI.

Comments: covered by both
Control /Action: Periodically assess the security controls in organizational systems to determine if the controls are effective in their application.

Comments: Covered under ICT & Cyber depending on standard chosen, in this case ISO 27002
Control /Action: Prevent non-privileged users from executing privileged functions and capture the execution of such functions in audit logs.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.   Not mentioned in DISP, but it can be considered covered under ISO 6.2.2 Teleworking if ISO27002 is covered
Control /Action: Prevent remote devices from simultaneously establishing non-remote connections with organizational systems and communicating via some other connection to resources in external networks (i.e., split tunneling).

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  This would be covered in detail under ISO 27002 if that is the chosen standard under 9.4.2 Secure log-on procedures
Control /Action: Prevent reuse of identifiers for a defined period.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP covers this under ICT and Cyber
depending on standard chosen, ISO 27002 discusses further under 12.1.4 Separation of development, testing and operational environments
Control /Action: Prevent unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  This would be covered in detail under ISO 27002 if that is the chosen standard
Control /Action: Prohibit password reuse for a specified number of generations.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP covers depending on the chosen ICT and
Cyber standard, ISO 27001/2 covers
Control /Action: Prohibit the use of portable storage devices when such devices have no identifiable owner.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Protect and monitor the physical facility and support infrastructure for organizational systems.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Protect audit information and audit logging tools from unauthorized access, modification, and deletion

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP does not mention this, depending on standard chosen, ISO 27002 13
Communications security
Control /Action: Protect the authenticity of communications sessions.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  DISP briefly mentions this and further
discusses on ICT and cyber and provides a comprehensive coverage of physical security of back up data, ISO 27002 covers under 12.3.1 Information backup
Control /Action: Protect the confidentiality of backup CUI at storage locations.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  DISP does not explicitly mention this, under ICT and Cyber, ISO 27002 covers under 18.1.3 Protection of records
Control /Action: Protect the confidentiality of CUI at rest.

Comments: This is not mentioned in DISP but covered under ISO 27002 13.1.2 Security of network services
Control /Action: Protect wireless access using authentication and encryption.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  Only indirectly implied in DISP but explicitly discussed in ISO 27002, 12.7 Information systems audit considerations
Control /Action: Provide a system capability that compares and synchronizes internal system clocks with an authoritative source to generate time stamps for audit records.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Provide audit record reduction and report generation to support on-demand analysis and reporting.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP accepts self- certification at entry level and uses CIOG (defence authority for accrediting systems) for all levels above 1 This is comprehensively covered in ISO 27002 if that is the chosen ICT standard under 14.2.2 System change control procedures
Control /Action: Provide controls on the tools, techniques, mechanisms, and personnel used to conduct system maintenance.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Provide security awareness training on recognizing and reporting potential indicators of insider threat.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP maintains an insider threat program with clear escalation pathways
Control /Action: Remediate vulnerabilities in accordance with risk assessments.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC Covered under ICT & Cyber depending on which cyber security standard is used in this case ISO 27001/2
Control /Action: Restrict, disable, or prevent the use of nonessential programs, functions, ports, protocols, and services.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC briefly
Control /Action: Review and update logged events.

Comments: Briefly mentioned in DISP under ICT and Cyber on securing cloud services
Control /Action: Route remote access via managed access control points.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Scan for vulnerabilities in organizational systems and applications periodically and when new vulnerabilities affecting those systems and applications are identified.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC.  Both models cover screening, DISP goes into details in depth about its screening
process in line with AS 4811-2006 employment screening process and maintains a DSAP list for clearance levels it also requires a description of the
screening process. DISP also mentions SO sponsoring clearances.
Control /Action: Screen individuals prior to authorizing access to organizational systems containing CUI.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC  Mentioned briefly on DISP, covered under ICT and Cyber depending on standard chosen.
Control /Action: Separate the duties of individuals to reduce the risk of malevolent activity without collusion.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP covers this under ICT and Cyber
depending on standard chosen, ISO 27002 discusses further under 9.1.2 Access to networks and network services
Control /Action: Separate user functionality from system management functionality.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC.   This would be covered in detail under ISO 27002 if that is the chosen standard under 9.4.2 Secure log-on procedures
Control /Action: Store and transmit only cryptographically protected passwords.

Comments:
Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP is covered under ISO 27002
11.2.4 Equipment maintenance
Control /Action: Supervise the maintenance activities of maintenance personnel without required access authorization.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Terminate (automatically) a user session after a defined condition.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC. DISP briefly covers this under ICT and Cyber and discusses further on ISO 27002 9.4.2 Secure log-on procedures
Control /Action: Terminate network connections associated with communications sessions at the end of the sessions or after a defined period of inactivity.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC, DISP requires maintain an inside thereat program with risks and mitigation strategies
Control /Action: Track, document, and report incidents to designated officials and/or authorities both internal and external to the organization

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Track, review, approve or disapprove, and log changes to organizational systems.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Use multifactor authentication for local and network access to privileged accounts and for network access to non-privileged accounts.

Comments: Covered under ICT & Cyber depending on standard chosen, in this case ISO 27002
Control /Action: Use non-privileged accounts or roles when accessing nonsecurity functions.

Comments: Covered under both DISP and CMMC
Control /Action: Use session lock with pattern-hiding displays to prevent access and viewing of data after a period of inactivity.

Control: Defence accreditation (IRAP assessor (expensive), Standalone device Defence network or device (dreams token, physical installation of DPN, DSN or TSN))
Comments: No mention in CMMC                          DISP requires defence accreditation of your network or standalone device (Levels 1,2,3)for entry level self accreditation with an IT service provider is allowed, CMMC does not
Control /Action: Get Defence accreditation of your network or standalone device

Control: Governance (CSO/SO – Chief Security Office/ Security Officer)
Comments: No mention in CMMC
Control /Action: Must have a nominated (CSO) and (SO) who must be able to meet AGSVA eligibility requirements for Baseline clearance)

Comments: No mention in CMMC
Control /Action: Report any substantial changes as soon as possible, including changes in Foreign Ownership, Control and Influence (FOCI) status

Comments: No mention in CMMC                                                        CMMC does not mention personnel clearance or the agency doing the clearance
Control /Action: Screening in tiered levels of Information access from official/sensitive, protected, secret and top secret
